fair_claims_settlement_practices.description: California Fair Claims Settlement Practices Regulations govern how insurers must handle claims fairly and in good faith.

provisions.title: Duty to Acknowledge Communications
provisions.requirement: Every insurer shall acknowledge receipt of every communication regarding a claim within 15 calendar days.
provisions.penalty: Administrative action, fines up to $10,000 per violation

provisions.title: Time for Investigation
provisions.requirement: Every insurer shall conduct and complete investigation of a claim within 40 calendar days after receiving proof of claim.
provisions.penalty: Administrative penalties and potential bad faith liability

provisions.title: Decision Communication
provisions.requirement: Insurer must accept or deny the claim in writing within 40 calendar days. If more time is needed, written notice with reasons must be provided every 30 days.
provisions.extensions: 30-day written updates required if investigation continues

provisions.title: Payment Upon Acceptance
provisions.requirement: Upon acceptance of a claim, payment shall be made within 30 calendar days.
provisions.penalty: Interest penalties and potential bad faith claims

provisions.title: Undisputed Amounts
provisions.requirement: If there is a dispute over the amount of a claim, the insurer must pay the undisputed portion within 30 days without requiring a release.

provisions.title: Written Denial Requirements
provisions.requirement: Every denial of a claim must be in writing, state all bases for denial, and reference specific policy provisions, conditions, or exclusions.

provisions.title: Proof of Loss Forms
provisions.requirement: If proof of claim forms are required, they must be provided within 15 days of receiving notice of claim.

provisions.title: Additional Information Requests
provisions.requirement: Requests for additional information must be made within 40 days of receiving initial proof of claim. Insurer may not request information already in their possession.

total_loss_regulations.description: Specific requirements for handling total loss vehicle claims in California.

provisions.title: Total Loss Threshold
provisions.requirement: A vehicle is considered a total loss when the cost of repairs plus the salvage value exceeds the actual cash value (ACV) of the vehicle.
provisions.formula: Total Loss if: Repair Cost + Salvage Value > ACV

provisions.title: Comparable Vehicle Valuation
provisions.requirement: When determining ACV using comparable vehicles, insurer must use at least two comparable vehicles from the local market area. Comparables must be of the same year, make, model, mileage, and condition.

provisions.title: Valuation Documentation
provisions.requirement: Insurer must provide claimant with a written statement of the basis for the settlement offer, including all sources and documents used to determine ACV.

provisions.title: Deductions Disclosure
provisions.requirement: Any deductions from ACV (such as for prior damage or salvage) must be itemized and explained in writing.

provisions.title: Sales Tax Reimbursement
provisions.requirement: Total loss settlements must include applicable sales tax, transfer fees, and registration fees that the claimant would incur to replace the vehicle.

provisions.title: Salvage Title Requirement
provisions.requirement: Vehicles declared a total loss must be reported to DMV. A salvage certificate is issued, and the vehicle cannot be operated until rebuilt and inspected.

provisions.title: Owner Retention Option
provisions.requirement: If policyholder wishes to retain the salvage, insurer must inform them of the deduction amount and any applicable salvage title requirements.
provisions.disclosure: Written notice of salvage deduction and title implications required

time_limits_and_deadlines.description: Critical time limits for California auto insurance claims processing.

deadlines.time_limit: 40 calendar days from proof of claim

deadlines.action: Accept or deny claim in writing
deadlines.time_limit: 40 calendar days from proof of claim

deadlines.action: Provide status update if investigation continues
Provide proof of claim forms if required

deadlines.time_limit: 40 calendar days from initial proof of claim

deadlines.action: Statute of limitations for filing lawsuit
deadlines.time_limit: 2 years from date of loss (breach of contract: 4 years)

required_disclosures.description: Mandatory disclosures insurers must provide to California policyholders and claimants.

disclosures.title: Claimant's Bill of Rights
disclosures.requirement: Insurers must provide a copy of the Claimant's Bill of Rights when requested or when a third-party claim is made.
content_includes: Right to prompt and fair claim handling
Right to receive written explanation of claim decision
Right to contact Department of Insurance

disclosures.title: Repair Shop Choice
disclosures.requirement: Insurer must inform claimant of their right to choose their own repair shop. Insurer cannot require use of a specific shop.

disclosures.title: Parts Disclosure
disclosures.requirement: Written estimate must clearly identify whether replacement parts are original equipment manufacturer (OEM), aftermarket, or used/recycled parts.

disclosures.title: Aftermarket Parts Notice
disclosures.requirement: If aftermarket parts are specified, insurer must disclose this fact and that the parts are not made by the original manufacturer.

disclosures.title: Appraisal Rights
disclosures.requirement: If there is a dispute over the amount of loss, policyholder must be informed of their right to invoke the appraisal clause in their policy.

disclosures.title: Rental Car Coverage Disclosure
disclosures.requirement: Insurer must clearly explain rental car coverage limits and duration at time of loss.

disclosures.title: Diminished Value Information
disclosures.requirement: For third-party claims, claimants may be entitled to diminished value compensation. Insurer should not discourage legitimate diminished value claims.

uninsured_underinsured_motorist.description: California requirements for uninsured and underinsured motorist coverage.

provisions.title: Mandatory Offer
provisions.requirement: Every auto policy must offer uninsured motorist (UM) coverage. The coverage must equal bodily injury liability limits unless the insured signs a written waiver for lower limits.

provisions.title: UM Coverage Minimum
provisions.requirement: Minimum UM limits if elected: $15,000 per person / $30,000 per accident for bodily injury.

provisions.title: Underinsured Motorist Coverage (UIM)
provisions.requirement: UIM coverage is optional in California but must be offered. UIM covers the difference between the at-fault driver's limits and the insured's UIM limits.

provisions.title: Arbitration Requirement
provisions.requirement: Disputes over UM/UIM coverage and amounts are subject to binding arbitration if parties cannot agree.

provisions.title: Hit and Run Coverage
provisions.requirement: UM coverage applies to hit-and-run accidents. Claimant must report to police within 24 hours and to insurer within 30 days.

anti_fraud_provisions.description: California insurance fraud detection and reporting requirements.

provisions.title: Fraud Warning Statement
provisions.requirement: All claim forms must contain a fraud warning statement: 'Any person who knowingly presents a false or fraudulent claim for the payment of a loss is guilty of a crime and may be subject to fines and confinement in state prison.'

provisions.title: Special Investigative Unit (SIU)
provisions.requirement: Insurers must maintain a Special Investigative Unit for detecting and investigating suspected fraudulent claims.

provisions.title: Fraud Reporting
provisions.requirement: Insurers must report suspected fraudulent claims to the California Department of Insurance Fraud Division within 60 days of determination.

provisions.title: Staged Accident Indicators
provisions.requirement: Claims with indicators of staged accidents must be investigated, including: multiple occupants claiming injury, witnesses who leave scene, prior claims history, and suspicious damage patterns.

provisions.title: Material Misrepresentation
provisions.requirement: Material misrepresentation on an application or claim may void coverage. Insurer must prove misrepresentation was material and made with intent to deceive.

repair_standards.description: California standards for auto repair in insurance claims.

provisions.title: Freedom to Choose Repair Shop
provisions.requirement: Claimant has absolute right to choose their own repair facility. Insurer cannot require repairs at a specific shop.

provisions.title: Direct Repair Programs
provisions.requirement: Insurers may recommend Direct Repair Program (DRP) shops but cannot mandate their use. Must disclose any financial arrangements with DRP shops.

provisions.title: Labor Rate Disputes
provisions.requirement: If insurer's labor rate is lower than the chosen shop's rate, insurer must pay the prevailing competitive labor rate in the area.

provisions.title: OEM Parts Requirement
provisions.requirement: Aftermarket parts can only be used if they are of 'like kind and quality.' Policyholder can request OEM parts (may pay difference).

provisions.title: Supplemental Claims
provisions.requirement: If additional damage is discovered during repairs, insurer must promptly inspect and authorize supplemental payment.

provisions.title: Repair Warranty
provisions.requirement: DRP shops must provide a warranty on repairs. Insurer must disclose warranty terms.

good_faith_requirements.description: California requirements for good faith claims handling and prohibited practices.

prohibited_practices.title: Misrepresenting Coverage
prohibited_practices.description: Misrepresenting pertinent facts or insurance policy provisions relating to coverages at issue.

prohibited_practices.title: Failing to Acknowledge Communications
prohibited_practices.description: Failing to acknowledge and act reasonably promptly upon communications with respect to claims.

prohibited_practices.title: Failing to Adopt Standards
prohibited_practices.description: Failing to adopt and implement reasonable standards for prompt investigation and processing of claims.

prohibited_practices.title: Denying Claims Without Investigation
prohibited_practices.description: Refusing to pay claims without conducting a reasonable investigation based upon available information.

prohibited_practices.title: Failing to Affirm or Deny Coverage
prohibited_practices.description: Failing to affirm or deny coverage of claims within a reasonable time after proof of loss requirements have been completed.

prohibited_practices.title: Low Settlement Offers
prohibited_practices.description: Not attempting in good faith to effectuate prompt, fair, and equitable settlements of claims in which liability has become reasonably clear.

prohibited_practices.title: Compelling Litigation
prohibited_practices.description: Compelling insureds to institute litigation to recover amounts due under an insurance policy by offering substantially less than the amounts ultimately recovered.

prohibited_practices.title: Delay Tactics
prohibited_practices.description: Attempting to settle a claim for less than the amount to which a reasonable person would have believed they were entitled by reference to advertising materials.

prohibited_practices.title: Excessive Documentation
prohibited_practices.description: Attempting to settle claims on the basis of an application altered without knowledge or consent of the insured.

prohibited_practices.title: Misleading Appeal Rights
prohibited_practices.description: Making known to insureds a policy of appealing from arbitration awards in favor of insureds or claimants for the purpose of compelling them to accept less.

prohibited_practices.title: Unreasonable Delays
prohibited_practices.description: Delaying the investigation or payment of claims by requiring unnecessary documents or creating unreasonable paperwork demands.

prohibited_practices.title: Failing to Settle
prohibited_practices.description: Failing to settle claims promptly where liability has become apparent under one portion of the policy to influence settlements under other portions.

prohibited_practices.title: Failing to Provide Forms
prohibited_practices.description: Failing to provide promptly a reasonable explanation of the basis in the insurance policy for denial of a claim or offer of a compromise settlement.

prohibited_practices.title: Direct Repair Pressure
prohibited_practices.description: Directly advising a claimant not to obtain the services of an attorney or adjustor.

prohibited_practices.title: Misleading Statute of Limitations
prohibited_practices.description: Misleading a claimant as to the applicable statute of limitations.

bad_faith_remedies.description: Remedies available to policyholders for insurer bad faith in California.

remedies.description: Damages for economic loss caused by the insurer's breach
Damages for emotional distress caused by bad faith conduct
Available when insurer's conduct is fraudulent, oppressive, or malicious
May be recoverable under Brandt v. Superior Court

bad_faith_remedies.reference: Egan v. Mutual of Omaha, Gruenberg v. Aetna

minimum_coverage_requirements.description: California minimum auto insurance coverage requirements.

requirements.description: Covers injuries to others when policyholder is at fault
Covers damage to others' property when policyholder is at fault

requirements.minimum_limit: $15,000 per person / $30,000 per accident (can be waived)
requirements.description: Covers policyholder's injuries from uninsured driver

financial_responsibility.description: California Vehicle Code requires proof of financial responsibility for all registered vehicles.

rental_car_coverage.description: California regulations regarding rental car coverage during claims.

provisions.title: Loss of Use Coverage
provisions.requirement: When liable for damage to another's vehicle, insurer may owe loss of use (rental) costs even if the vehicle is not actually rented.

provisions.title: Reasonable Rental Period
provisions.requirement: Rental coverage should extend for reasonable repair period plus reasonable time to obtain replacement for total loss.

provisions.title: First-Party Rental Reimbursement
provisions.requirement: If policy includes rental reimbursement, insurer must clearly explain daily and aggregate limits.

provisions.title: Class of Vehicle
provisions.requirement: Rental should be comparable class to the damaged vehicle, not necessarily identical make/model.

medical_payments_coverage.description: California regulations for medical payments (MedPay) coverage.

provisions.title: Optional Coverage
provisions.requirement: Medical payments coverage is optional in California. Must be offered but can be declined.

provisions.title: No-Fault Coverage
provisions.requirement: MedPay is no-fault coverage - pays regardless of who caused the accident.

provisions.title: Coordination with Health Insurance
provisions.requirement: MedPay typically pays secondary to health insurance. Cannot subrogate against insured's own coverage.

subrogation_rules.description: California rules governing subrogation in auto insurance claims.

provisions.title: Right of Subrogation
provisions.requirement: After paying a claim, insurer is subrogated to insured's rights against third parties to the extent of payment.

provisions.title: Made Whole Doctrine
provisions.requirement: California follows the 'made whole' doctrine - insurer cannot pursue subrogation until insured is fully compensated for losses.
provisions.reference: Sapiano v. Williamsburg Nat'l Ins. Co.

provisions.title: Common Fund Doctrine
provisions.requirement: If insured recovers from third party, insurer's subrogation share may be reduced by proportionate share of attorney fees.

provisions.title: Anti-Subrogation Rule
provisions.requirement: Insurer cannot subrogate against its own insured or additional insureds under the same policy.

consumer_services.description: Consumers can file complaints about claim handling practices
Information about insurance rates and rate approval process
Verify insurance agent, broker, and company licenses

enforcement_actions.description: The CDI can impose penalties for regulatory violations.
penalties: Administrative fines up to $10,000 per violation

proposition_103.description: California's landmark insurance reform initiative passed in 1988.

key_provisions.title: Rate Approval
key_provisions.description: All auto insurance rate changes must be approved by the Insurance Commissioner before taking effect.

key_provisions.title: Rating Factors
key_provisions.description: Auto insurance rates must be based primarily on driving safety record, years of driving experience, and annual miles driven. Territory cannot be primary factor.

key_provisions.title: Good Driver Discount
key_provisions.description: Insurers must offer at least 20% discount to 'good drivers' - those with no more than one point on their record in past 3 years.

key_provisions.title: Anti-Discrimination
key_provisions.description: Cannot refuse to insure or charge higher rates based on race, color, religion, national origin, or ancestry.

statute_of_limitations.description: Time limits for legal actions related to auto insurance claims in California.
tolling_provisions: Minor claimants: Statute tolled until age 18
Incapacitated claimants: Statute tolled during incapacity
Defendant out of state: May toll statute

common_claim_scenarios.description: Guidance for common California auto claim scenarios.

scenarios.presumption: Rear driver presumed at fault under California law
scenarios.exceptions: Sudden stop, cut-off, brake check may reduce liability
Through driver running red light, excessive speed

scenarios.rule: California follows pure comparative negligence - claimant can recover even if 99% at fault (reduced by their percentage)

scenarios.note: Uninsured driver can still recover under comparative fault but may face penalties
Insurer generally must cover damages to third parties even if insured was DUI
scenarios.exception: Some policies exclude coverage for intentional acts or criminal conduct

scenarios.rule: Coverage generally extends to permissive users of insured vehicle

electronic_claims_requirements.description: California requirements for electronic claims handling.

provisions.title: Electronic Communications
provisions.requirement: Insurers may communicate electronically if claimant consents. Written disclosures must be provided regarding electronic delivery.

provisions.title: Electronic Signatures
provisions.requirement: Electronic signatures are valid for insurance transactions under California UETA.

provisions.title: Records Retention
provisions.requirement: Claims records must be retained for at least 5 years.
